Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2007 07:06AM - edited Oct 27, 2007 07:07AM by Kara Unfortunately there is no crystal ball.  And you must make the decision that you feel is best for yourself. Do your best to research the different chemotherapy drugs.  A site I found useful for looking up the different drugs (any prescription drug) was: http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginformation.html Make sure you understand all of the side effects - short term as well as any possible long term effects.  Weigh those against the benefits you would get. Once you've done some research on your own, if you need to, meet with your onco again.  Or get a 2nd or 3rd opinion. Good-luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 08:11PM karens-kara-van wrote: Hi my name is Karen stage 4 triple pos from dx dec of 05. Organs and bones clean but lots of lymph node involvement and nasty frustrating skin mets. Been on every chemotherapy out there including hormone blockers xeloda tykerb faslodex you name it and I have been on it. Even have done drugs twice. In July I felt very scared skin mets out of control and running out of options. Searching clinical trials I did all the research on TDM1 and I felt this is the drug I need to be on. My onc did not agree and said I was not a candidate. I emailed all the sites with my story and sure enough got an appt. In Fairfax Va cancer center. I live in N.Y. But trial was not offered here. After a ton of tests and 3weeks of no treatment they let me in the trial. Not a blind study the expanded access trial. So I knew I was getting the real thing. I did six cycles in Va. After six cycles and a much improved pet and healing skin mets, they allowed me to transition to Sloan Kettering in N.Y. I just finished my 2nd cycle here at Sloan and another good scan. Skin mets not gone but under control. I have felt better in the last six months than I have in 6 years. I have not a side effect. nothing! My labs are all great and my energy level is like new. I feel so blessed to be on TDM1 and pray it works for a very long time! We really have to be our own advocates when it comes to this horrible disease. This drug needs to be approved! I started this trial in Aug and they closed it in sept. I just made it, but I definitely fought to get it! Peace to all!

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 11:02PM - edited Nov 30, 2007 11:40PM by Kara Karyll, You have such a wonderful outlook.  The body has an amazing way of healing itself and sleep is the best time for healing to take place.  I like my meditation CDs because they talk about relaxing the different parts of the body and releasing any tension and to send white light of healing to different parts.  I usually fall asleep listening to them (I get very relaxed) but I feel good when I wake up. Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2007 07:36AM - edited Dec 20, 2007 07:52AM by Kara Lori, The synthetic wigs are so EASY to take care of.  I've washed mine a few times and it's really just "wash, let try 'n wear". Brush:  Use a special wig brush.  Anything else may pull hairs out.  It's a wire brush with widely spaced "bristles". Before you wash it, brush it out. Put cool water in a sink, add a bit of shampoo (I've been using baby shampoo) and swish the wig around in the soapy water.  Rinse it with cool water.  I then roll mine in a towel to get most of the water out.  Put it on wire wigs stand or paper towel roll to dry.  You want air to be able to get to it from all sides so it will dry quickly. Do NOT put the wig on the styrofoam head while it's wet.  I was told this would cause it to stretch out of shape. Do NOT brush it when it's wet.  If you want to, use your fingers to put the hairs back into place a little. When it's dry, you can brush it.  I found I didn't have to do anything to get it back to it's original style. You can also find wig care tips on the Look Good, Feel Better site: http://www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org/women/hair_help/wig_care.htm Also, be sure to keep it away from HEAT.  Do NOT open an oven door when you're wearing it ... it will frizz up. I'm glad you switch radiologists and now like the people in the office.  It will make your treatments more pleasant.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 09:46PM - edited Oct 22, 2007 09:46PM by Kara Okay, I'm laying in bed after waking up in the middle of the night.  I got to thinking last night if the length of the hair affects how much prickley/sharp sensations one feels on their scalp when losing their hair. My husband shaved my hair to 1/2" all over.  He was afraid to cut it shorter.  At this length, the hair is able to lay flat on my head in the direction it grows.  I only feel a prickley/sharp sensation on my scalp if the hair gets rubbed to the opposite direction from which it grows.  Sometimes I feel it when resting my head on something and moving it around. I cannot say about the extra skin you have under your arm - I guess it depends on if it bothers your or not.  Can they use that skin to reconstruct your nipple/areolar?  My PS used skin from my hip.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 11:59PM Kara wrote: Hello Ladies.  I had a bi-lateral mastecomy on June 27th with TRAM Flap reconstruction.  I was diagnosed with DCIS on the left breast and LCIS on the right ... Stage 1.  My Oncotype DX was a 21.  So I was going to start Chemotherapy about 6 weeks after the surgery in August (4 treatments, 3 weeks apart) followed by hormone therapy for 5 years. In August, I found out I had two nodules on my thyroid which turned out to be suspicious for Papillary Carcinoma.  In September I had my thyroid removed and had to postpone Chemo for another 2 weeks. The Friday before I was to start Chemo, I discovered an absyssed tooth (one I'd had a root canal on earlier in the year).  I ended up having the tooth pulled and Chemo delayed another two weeks.  I bet the oncologist thought I was trying to avoid him.  My first Chemo treatment was on October 1st. And the oncologist kept asking me if I was okay; if anything else  happened in the last 5 minutes.  Nope.  I was fine. I received Taxotere followed by Cytoxan.  It probably took about 2-3 hours.  I did not have any reactions during the treatments ... well except the cold arm/hand from the cold IV.  A jacket helped keep my arm warmer.  I watched some movies during the treatment and ate lunch. I guess I was pumped full of steriods because I did have a little trouble sleeping for a few days.  I'll ask the oncologist if I can take Melatonin or something to help next time. I got the neulasta shot on Oct 2nd and only felt slight twinges now and then in my joints/bones. I feel good and have even been able to continue exercising on our Nordic Track machine and taking walks around the block with our dog. I have the anti-nauseau medications on hand (just in case).  I did take a stool softener (to keep things moving along) and then was fine. I haven't cut my hair short yet.  I do have a wig on hand for when I need it. 1 down and 3 to go! Hugs to all. Karen

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2007 09:31PM Kara wrote: Debbie, Your wig looks wonderful.  And your son is adorable. Linda, I am also receiving the same tx as you ... taxotere and cytoxan.  The only se's I had were the constipation (which was helped by colace and as Lori mentioned, starting colace earlier will help) and some achiness after the neulasta shot (helped with Tylenol).  I did have trouble sleeping during the nights around my 1st tx.  My onco gave me a prescription for a mild sleeping pill to take as needed during my 2nd tx.  My onco told me that "most people" have the same experience for the 2nd and additional treatements.  Of course he stressed the "most people" part as there could be exceptions.  My 2nd treatment went as well as the first and I even had less achiness after the neulasta (must be the over 50 thing) and I didn't need to take a sleeping pill.  I eat a healthy diet (low carbohydrate) of mostly fruits, vegetables, meats and cheese (no junk food, breads, potatoes, rice, etc) and I exercise just about every day and go for a walk with our dog every day. Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2007 04:16PM - edited Dec 17, 2007 04:36PM by Kara Just popping in from the October 2007 group.  I had a bi-lateral mastectomy with tram flap reconstruction in June 2007 and was supposed to start Chemo 6-8 weeks afterwards.  I was delayed 1st due to needing to have my thyroid removed and then again because I had to have a tooth pulled. I just finished 4 rounds of Taxotere and Cytoxan 3 weeks apart on December 3rd.  I felt pretty good throughout.  Some constipation (get peri-colace) and fatigue.  Some foods didn't quite taste the same.  I seemed to have tolerated the TC well.  I was also on disability from work during that time so I was able to get plenty of rest.  It was scary not knowing what to expect.  I didn't know how I'd feel during the treatment or afterwards.  I really didn't feel much during the tx, but my arm and hand did get cold (take a soft small blanket with you in case you need to wrap your arm up for warmth).  I felt about the same during and after each tx. I just want to stress to you ... LISTEN to your body and get REST when you need it.  Don't try to do too much too early. Keep a count-down of your treatments going.  It's nice when you can start checking off each treatment and can see the last one coming into sight. Here is a link to some helpful tips for dealing with the side effects: http://community.breastcancer.org/topic/69/conversation/478386?page=1 As for wigs, my insurance company said they didn't cover a wig.  I had my Dr write out a prescription for a Hair Prothesis and the Wigs store wrote Hair Prothesis on the receipt.  I submitted a claim to my insurance and they paid for the whole thing!!  Even though they said they don't cover wigs.  Submit a claim for it in case they will pay for it.
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 08:02AM Kara wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy with TRAM Flap reconstruction on June 27th.  I was in the hospital for four days.  The plastic surgeon had an epidural put in prior to the surgery and it did not come out until the day I was to leave the hospital.  I also had one of the push button to administer pain medication. I think I only used it once or twice the first day - the drugs make you sleepy.  I didn't take any pain medications once I was home.  Maybe I have a high tolerance for pain. They get you up and walking again the day after surgery.  I didn't really want to walk and it was hard getting out of bed.  I had to walk hunched over a bit so as to not pull the stitches.  It was very hard but walking does start to help you feel better and relieves the neasusea.  As others mentioned, you have to be very careful when you get up.  Your body will let you know the right way to move.  Listen to it!  When you're home you will need to sleep propped up using pillows.  My husband bought me two pillow wedges to put under my head/back.  That helped.  I also slept on the couch sitting up for the first few nights home. I think I was able to drive again about a week after surgery providing I wasn't taking any pain medication. About a week after surgery, my plastic surgeon had me put into a surgical girdle ... did anyone else have one of those??  It had hooks & eyes and zippers up the sides and ends just below the bust.  It keeps the abdomen compressed.  I had to wear it 24/7.  I'm sure it helped keep things in place and fluids from building up. A week later, they put me into a surgical girdle without the zippers and in one two sizes smaller!!  It took two nurses to pull it up on me and when they did, they lifted me off the floor!  It was so funny.  I was worried about getting it on again at home after a shower, but it does stretch.  I ended up buying a 2nd one so I'd have one to wash and one to wear. Don't try to overdo it.  Take the time to recuperate.  I started going for walks around the block (slowly) until my plastic surgeon told me that was too much like exercise and not to.  It caused some fluids to build up and he had to drain it using a syringe.  Not fun, so take it easy and let your body get the rest it needs. My breast surgeon gave me a CD and book "Prepare For Surgery, Heal Faster" (I think that's the title).  It uses guided imagery and relaxation techniques.  It must work because I'd fall asleep while listening to it.  (www.healfaster.com) Best wishes. Karen
